dialogue_history.content:
Analyze this financial news and estimate stock price movement probabilities.
Company: Apple Inc. (AAPL)
News Headline: TikTok says 'in the process of restoring service' after going dark in US, citing Trump 'clarity'
News Content: TikTok said Sunday afternoon it was in the process of restoring service to its US users after going dark overnight when a new law banning the app took effect at midnight.

In a post on X Sunday afternoon, TikTok said, "In agreement with our service providers, TikTok is in the process of restoring service. We thank President Trump for providing the necessary clarity and assurance to our service providers that they will face no penalties providing TikTok to over 170 million Americans and allowing over 7 million small businesses to thrive."

In a social media post on Sunday, Trump asked tech companies to "not let TikTok stay dark" and reiterated his plan to issue a reprieve once he takes office.

"I will issue an executive order on Monday to extend the period of time before the law’s prohibitions take effect, so that we can make a deal to protect our national security,” Trump posted. “The order will also confirm that there will be no liability for any company that helped keep TikTok from going dark before my order."

TikTok's statement followed roughly two hours later.

Beginning late Saturday, US TikTok users were shown a message saying the app wasn't available, citing the new law.

The alert also mentioned Trump by name saying, "We are fortunate that President Trump has indicated that he will work with us on a solution to reinstate TikTok once he takes office."

On its website, TikTok told users they could still login to download their data. As of Sunday afternoon, that message had been updated to read: "We're working hard to resolve this issue. Thank you for your patience."TikTok went dark Saturday night, just ahead of a ban on Sunday. (Source: Yahoo Finance/Dan Howley)·Howley

Still, many on Capitol Hill — not to mention outside experts — questioned whether Trump will have the authority to make good on these promises.

Some of Trump’s closest political allies are also the most outspoken critics of TikTok, and have so far stood by the law that they passed last April with strong bipartisan margins.

In a statement early Sunday, Republican Sens. Tom Cotton and Pete Ricketts said, "now that the law has taken effect, there’s no legal basis for any kind of 'extension' of its effective date." Cotton added earlier this week on the Senate floor that "there will be no extension, no concession, and no compromises for TikTok."

Story Continues

House Speaker Mike Johnson, another top Trump ally, also raised questions Sunday, telling NBC he wanted to see the current law enforced and that he is "really heartened to see that Google and Apple and Microsoft have taken the steps to comply with the law."

The back-and-forth between Trump, TikTok, and US lawmakers will remain in acute relief on Monday, with TikTok CEO Shou Zi Chew expected to be in attendance at inauguration events.

Rolling shutdown

Access to TikTok began getting cut off for some US users about 90 minutes before the new law took effect late Saturday. The app was also unavailable via Apple's App Store in the hours leading up to midnight. Videos intermittently loaded on TikTok for a time, but the app also showed a blacked-out screen indicating network issues.

Saturday night's rolling cutoff for US TikTok users followed a report from The Information which said Oracle (ORCL), which manages TikTok's US servers, was set to begin shutting down servers that host TikTok's data as early as 9:00 p.m. ET.

The law that has resulted in TikTok's shutdown doesn't outright ban the app, but rather it prohibits users from accessing the platform through app stores, like those run by Apple (AAPL) and Google (GOOG, GOOGL), and cloud services unless parent company ByteDance sells itself to an owner that is not controlled by a country the US considers adversarial.

Congress has accused ByteDance of having close ties to the Chinese government and alleges that the Chinese Communist Party could force the company to provide it with information on US users or otherwise spread propaganda on the platform.

But the outcry from users and TikTok's backers forced President Joe Biden and Trump to respond. Even with Trump's assurances Apple and Google that his administration won't enforce the law, it's not guaranteed that his — or any other administration — would do so in the future. Each time the companies don't comply with the law they'd have to pay a fine of $5,000 each time a user accesses the social media app.

Trump will have to either convince Congress to overturn the ban or find some other way to work around it if he wants to keep the service up and running, and neither of those is simple.

'It's a good thing for Meta'

Should TikTok's ban eventually come to pass, one of the biggest winners could be one of TikTok’s long-term critics: Meta (META) CEO Mark Zuckerberg. In particular, Instagram, owned by Meta, could see a sizable uptick in advertiser dollars if TikTok bites the dust.

“In general, it’s a good thing for Meta,” William Blair research analyst Ralph Schackart told Yahoo Finance. “We estimate in a note potentially 60% to 70% of TikTok spend could move to Instagram and it monetizes at around 3x the rate of TikTok.”

Social media companies have been chasing TikTok’s formula in an attempt to copy the social media platform’s success for some time. Reddit (RDDT), for example, offers its own short-form video feed that could entice former TikTok users looking for a broader kind of social media site complete with various message boards and communities.

Snapchat (SNAP) could also grab users who would have otherwise spent time on TikTok — and the advertising dollars that follow. But as Morgan Stanley managing director Brian Nowak points out, Snap would have to ensure it can keep those TikTok refugees coming back over and over again — as TikTok does — if it hopes to hold onto that ad revenue.

Pinterest (PINS) also stands to get a boost if TikTok is forced to go dark. While the app doesn’t have much in common with TikTok as far as overall design, it could offer an opportunity for online retailers looking to drum up e-commerce sales, something TikTok has managed to do thanks to its army of influencers.Sign up for Yahoo Finance's Week in Tech newsletter.·yahoofinance

With additional reporting from Ben Werschkul.

Alexis Keenan is a legal reporter for Yahoo Finance. Follow Alexis on X @alexiskweed.

Email Daniel Howley at dhowley@yahoofinance.com. Follow him on Twitter at @DanielHowley.

Next I will provide you some predictions of stock price movement probabilities and the corresponding analysis by others in the previous rounds.
Note that others' predictions may indicate that they have some other information about the stock price. A high prediction may indicate that they have some positive information about the stock, while a low prediction may indicate that they have some megative information about the stock.
Also note that there are multiple rounds of precitions, demonstrating the trend of others' beliefs.
Please take these information into consideration when prediction the stock price movement probabilities.
Previous predictions:
Round: 0
Model: openai/gpt-4o-mini, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.55, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.45, Reasoning: The news regarding TikTok's service restoration and Trump's involvement suggests a potential easing of regulatory pressure on tech companies like Apple. However, the uncertainty surrounding the enforcement of the law and the bipartisan support for it raises concerns. While there may be a short-term positive sentiment due to the potential for TikTok to remain operational, the long-term implications of regulatory scrutiny could weigh on Apple's stock. Therefore, the probabilities reflect a cautious optimism about a rise in stock price, balanced by the risk of a fall due to regulatory uncertainties.
Model: google/gemini-2.0-flash-001, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.55, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.45, Reasoning: The news regarding TikTok's potential ban and subsequent restoration of service has mixed implications for Apple (AAPL). On one hand, a TikTok ban could benefit Apple indirectly as users and advertisers might shift to platforms accessible through the App Store, potentially increasing Apple's revenue from app sales and in-app purchases. However, the uncertainty surrounding the ban, the political maneuvering, and the potential for a reversal create volatility. The fact that the app was briefly unavailable on the App Store could also be seen as a negative, highlighting the potential for future disruptions. The news also mentions that Google and Microsoft have taken steps to comply with the law, which could be interpreted as a sign that the ban is likely to proceed. Given these conflicting factors, the impact on Apple's stock price is uncertain, but the potential for increased app store revenue is a slightly positive factor. The probability of a rise is slightly higher than a fall, but not by a large margin.
Model: google/gemini-flash-1.5, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.2, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.3, Reasoning: The news article discusses the temporary shutdown and subsequent restoration of TikTok in the US due to a new law.  While the initial shutdown might have seemed positive for Apple (as it removed a competitor from the App Store), the subsequent restoration, driven by Trump's intervention, negates this positive impact.  The uncertainty surrounding the future of TikTok in the US, coupled with the legal challenges and political infighting, creates a neutral to slightly negative outlook for Apple.  Apple's involvement is indirect; the law affects their App Store's compliance and potential fines. The potential for significant fines if Apple doesn't comply is a risk, but the likelihood of a complete and permanent TikTok ban remains uncertain.  The article also highlights potential benefits for Meta, a competitor, which could indirectly negatively impact Apple's stock price if users shift to Meta's platforms. Therefore, the probability of a stock price rise is low, while the probability of a fall is also relatively low, leaning towards a neutral outcome.
Model: deepseek/deepseek-chat-v3-0324, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.45, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.4, Reasoning: The news primarily discusses the temporary shutdown and potential restoration of TikTok services in the US, with implications for tech companies like Apple (AAPL). Apple's App Store was mentioned as one of the platforms affected by the TikTok ban. The uncertainty around the ban's enforcement and potential political resolutions could create volatility. However, Apple's diversified business model and strong ecosystem may mitigate significant negative impact. The news does not directly indicate a major positive or negative catalyst for Apple's stock, but the resolution of the TikTok issue could restore some stability. Given the mixed signals and lack of direct financial impact on Apple, the probabilities are balanced with a slight tilt towards no significant movement.

However, given that TikTok's availability does not directly correlate with Apple's core business or revenue streams significantly, and considering that TikTok's ban or availability does not directly influence Apple's major services or products, the immediate impact on Apple's stock price might be minimal. The situation could potentially benefit competitors in the social media space or related sectors but does not directly threaten Apple's core business. Therefore, the probability of the stock price rising or falling due to this news seems relatively low, unless broader market sentiments or regulatory actions against TikTok influence investor perceptions about Apple's ecosystem and services.

Now give your prediction about the probability of the stock price of the relevant company rising or falling. Format your response in JSON format and include the following information as follows: 
{ 
"reasoning": "[Summarize your analysis and reasoning process here]", 
"company_name": "[Company Name indicating the name of the company]", 
"company_symbol": "[Company Symbol indicating the stock symbol of the company]", 
"news_headline": "[News Headline indicating the provided financial news headline]", 
"probability_of_stock_price_rise": [The estimated probability (a number between 0 and 1) that the stock price will rise due to this news], 
"probability_of_stock_price_fall": [The estimated probability (a number between 0 and 1) that the stock price will fall due to this news], 
} 
Do not generate output that isn't in properly formatted JSON.

```json
{
  "reasoning": "The news regarding TikTok's temporary ban and subsequent restoration creates significant uncertainty for Apple.  The direct impact on Apple is minimal, as the core business is unaffected. However, the situation introduces several indirect factors.  A prolonged TikTok ban could benefit Apple through increased App Store revenue as users and advertisers shift to other platforms. Conversely, the uncertainty surrounding the ban's enforcement, the potential for fines if Apple doesn't comply, and the possibility of competitors like Meta gaining market share create significant downside risk.  The political maneuvering and conflicting statements from lawmakers add to the volatility.  Analysis of previous predictions reveals a lack of consensus, with probabilities fluctuating around 0.5 for both rise and fall.  Considering the mixed signals and the lack of a clear positive or negative catalyst directly affecting Apple's core business, the probabilities are weighted towards a neutral outcome, with a slight edge towards no significant change. The overall uncertainty outweighs any potential positive impact from increased App Store activity.",
  "company_name": "Apple Inc.",
  "company_symbol": "AAPL",
  "news_headline": "TikTok says 'in the process of restoring service' after going dark in US, citing Trump 'clarity'",
  "probability_of_stock_price_rise": 0.49,
  "probability_of_stock_price_fall": 0.51
}
```
